Award.AbstractNarration:
Autonomous systems in general and self-driving cars in particular, hold the promise to be one of the most disruptive technologies emerging in recent years. However, the safety and resilience of these systems, if not proactively addressed, will pose a significant threat potentially impairing our relationship with these technologies and may lead to a societal rejection of adopting them permanently. This project seeks to address such concerns by equipping autonomous systems with an additional layer of intelligence allowing them to be resilient-by-cognition.

The research addresses resilience for autonomous cyber-physical systems (CPS) by integrating concepts from game theory, formal methods, and controls. Our proposed approach includes: (i) a principled framework for formally reasoning about cognitive CPS; that is, given a set of strategies captured in a formal language (e.g., temporal logic), the proposed framework builds on ideas from evolutionary game theory to understand which strategies lead to the best fit when operating in adversarial environments (ii) On-the-fly, correct-by-design feedback controller synthesis that executes the chosen strategy while satisfying physical constraints imposed by the micro-dynamics of the underlying CPS (iii) a data-driven strategy-mining approach that addresses the fundamental problem of designing the library of strategies from human demonstrations. We will illustrate our approach over key applications including self-driving cars and autonomous drone swarms. Our educational plan engages not only graduate students but also high school and undergraduate students. It also reaches out to engineers and the lay public, by providing open source implementations of our algorithms making them available both to industry and independent developers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project delved into enhancing the safety and resilience of autonomous cyber-physical systems (CPS) in challenging environments. To achieve this, a three-layer intelligence framework was developed, focusing on making these systems resilient through cognitive capabilities. At the top of this hierarchy is an innovative cognitive control layer, incorporating the principles of evolutionary game theory. Specifically, the study concentrated on a well-known framework within evolutionary game theory, known as replicator dynamics. Key questions addressed include the optimization goals of replicator dynamics' natural selection equations, the development of a broader theory for evolutionary games, and leveraging this understanding to create a novel control theory for guiding autonomous systems in adversarial contexts.

A significant challenge within this three-layer cognitive control architecture is the synthesis of a low-level controller that aligns with the requirements set by the higher cognitive layers. This synthesis must occur in real-time. The research focused on exploring scalable solvers capable of generating these low-level controllers while adhering to logical and structural constraints. Two complementary techniques were studied: the first utilized advancements in Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning to expedite controller synthesis, while the second harnessed the capabilities of deep neural networks as low-level controllers. Addressing the logical and structural constraints of the top cognitive layer was a central aspect, emphasizing novel correct-by-design approaches for training low-level neural network controllers. The practical application of this approach was demonstrated in key scenarios, such as self-driving cars and autonomous drone swarms.

Additionally, the project delved into creating human locomotion models using affine geometric methods and power laws. These models equipped autonomous vehicles with cognitive skills to understand human motion patterns during close-range operations. Drawing on recent observations that human movement velocity and curvature follow the "two-thirds power law," the research aimed to bridge the gap between human and robot movement. The optimal control of robots, considering these human-movement constraints, was explored.
